[h1]else[/h1]

The [b]else [/b]statement is most commonly used along with the [b]if[/b] statement, but it can also follow a [b]for [/b]or [b]while [/b]loop, which gives it a different meaning. 
With the [b]for [/b]or [b]while [/b]loop, the code within it is called if the loop finishes normally (when a [b]break [/b]statement does not cause an exit from the loop).

[b]Example:[/b][code format="py" codeId="450"][b]for[/b] i in range(10):
   if i == 999:
      break
[b]else:[/b]
   print("Unbroken 1")

[b]for [/b]i in range(10):
   if i == 5:
      break
[b]else: [/b]
   print("Unbroken 2")[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
Unbroken 1
>>>[/code]
[note]The first [b]for [/b]loop executes normally, resulting in the printing of "Unbroken 1".
The second loop exits due to a [b]break[/b], which is why it's [b]else [/b]statement is not executed.[/note]

[h1]else[/h1]

The [b]else[/b] statement can also be used with [b]try/except[/b] statements. 
In this case, the code within it is only executed if no error occurs in the [b]try [/b]statement.
[b]Example:[/b][code format="py" codeId="451"][b]try:[/b]
   print(1)
[b]except [/b]ZeroDivisionError:
   print(2)
[b]else:[/b]
   print(3)

[b]try:[/b]
   print(1/0)
[b]except [/b]ZeroDivisionError:
   print(4)
[b]else:[/b]
   print(5)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
1
3
4
>>>[/code]
